awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Remotely Operated Vehicles for Engaging and Retaining STEM Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a collaborative project involving Brevard College (Award DUE-1607952) and the Pisgah Astronomical Research Institute (PARI) (Award DUE-1607926). The investigators will redesign "gateway" STEM courses at a small liberal arts college around active-learning exercises and laboratories using technology, and will examine the effects on the engagement and retention of students in STEM. Specifically, over 400 students per year in introductory science classes at Brevard College will control remote rovers with sensors in the exploration of a 200-acre plot in the Pisgah National Forest in western North Carolina. Using an array of sensors, such as cameras, thermometers, soil moisture detectors, and a drill for geology studies, the remote-controlled robots will probe the forested environment. A submersible to study the water quality of stream-fed ponds is also part of the robot group. Students will experience the excitement of becoming researchers and guiding the rovers to explore. They will learn about flora and fauna and develop 21st-century technology skills needed in the STEM workforce. By using broadly applicable, state-of-the-art technology, the project will engage and inspire undergraduate students and faculty, while creating a set of institutional tools to share with peer institutions and informal science education centers.

The integration of engaging, experiential approaches using the rovers will create a rich learning environment in which students will see the connection between scientific theory and practice. Freshmen-level courses that will be affected include chemistry, biology, environmental science, geology, and physics. All students graduating from the college take at least one of the science courses plus one mathematics course. Instructors will incorporate the robotic manipulation, collection, and interpretation of data into these courses, especially the laboratory portions. By examining the rates of engagement and retention of students in STEM before and after the robotic technology has been implemented, the investigators will advance knowledge about the impact of innovative technology on undergraduate STEM education. The forest habitat data that will be gathered will also be valuable. A habitat map of a section of a national forest, which can be a longitudinal study, is important for environmental scientists and ecologists. Components of the project will be replicated and used at other colleges and science education centers, beginning with PARI, where educators plan to expand the project to summer and after-school programs, especially SciGirls and the North Carolina Girls STEM Collaborative.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of the Remotely Operated Vehicles for Engaging and Retaining Stem Students (ROVERS) program is to advance knowledge on the effect of innovative technology to improve STEM education. The broader impacts of this project are to engage and inspire STEM undergraduate students and faculty while creating new tools to share with peer institutions and informal science education centers. The three goals of the ROVERS project are to: 1) engage students in a dynamic classroom environment; 2) provide professional development opportunities for faculty with an emphasis on best practices in STEM education; and 3) to promote individual student research.

 

The outcome of Goal 1 was the establishment of new innovative curricula by several faculty, which centered on the use of a remotely operated rover with weather, GPS, and other sensors. These faculty developed and implemented lesson plans in a variety of classrooms including Chemistry, Biology, Physics, Mathematics, and Environmental Studies. The first generation rover was developed in concert with our partner institution, the Pisgah Astronomical Research Institute. It required a set of text entry instructions and a lag time for operation, complicating use of the rover, but during the second year of the grant, we transitioned to the NASA JPL Opensource rover model.  Our student interns, along with faculty, built the JPL rover and implemented its software that uses a joystick and intuitive instructions to operate the rover. With the new rover and intuitive interface, faculty reported more excitement and engagement of our students in the classroom. This shift toward ease of use for both students and faculty was a major development and outcome, as was the use of an opensource model available to the public. Over the course of the grant, retention of STEM majors was 85% (as compared to 64% overall retention at our college).  Interest and retention was especially dramatic among younger majors, rising from 3.4% of declared STEM majors who were sophomores prior to the start of the grant up to 31% of STEM majors who were sophomores by the grant's conclusion.

 

The outcome of Goal 2 was professional development for faculty that centered on curriculum.  Each academic year, the participating faculty were trained in the capabilities of the rover and developed curricula that incorporated its use in their classrooms.  In the first year, the capabilities of the rover were fixed and faculty did not have the ability to change or modify the rover.  In the second year, a new rover allowed for modifications by faculty, and a new weather station was added to broaden rover curricular use.  In the third year faculty added additional sensors and modified their curriculum objectives around these sensors and other improvements to usability.  Faculty found new and exciting approaches to STEM education that are reflected in the positive STEM retention rates.  In addition to curriculum development, several faculty also presented the ROVERS project at two Appalachian College Association Annual Summits, and one National Science Teacher Association conference.  These meetings provided a path to sharing the ROVERS project and generated interest by educators from other college and high school systems. We also worked with one local K-12 public high school and one private organization for at-risk youth to teach each program how to build and operate rovers for science education.  

 

The outcome of Goal 3 was to provide individual students with research experience. In the first year of the project, two interns became experts at controlling and understanding the abilities and limits of the rover.  With their new skill and knowledge, they facilitated workshops for the faculty who were developing ROVERS curricula, and it was the student interns who taught the teachers. STEM education for these students was not only learning, but also teaching concepts that could be used in the classroom.  The second year interns followed in the footsteps of the first, but with the additional experience of building and operating a new rover ? a new piece of scientific equipment that would be used in the classroom.  When facilitating the faculty workshops, the second year interns were confident because of their familiarity with the rover through hardware construction and software testing. The third year interns expanded the materials available to faculty for use and control of the rover.  They modified a manual produced in the second year and built a webpage with complete details about the rover, including sensors, software, videos, and manuals. They also managed the day-to-day use and troubleshooting of the new rover. Thus the student interns became the experts, the teachers, and the managers as they learned the intricacies of the entire project, a true research experience for these students. All interns reported that their involvement in the project improved their opportunities and expectations for either graduate school or entering the workforce immediately after graduation.
